title: brexit news jacob rees mogg house of lords petition
story: Jacob Rees-Mogg said the unelected House of Lords was risking its very existence by stubbornly attempting to disrupt the Brexit process.His comments came after a petition calling for a referendum on abolishing the House of Lords passed the 100,000 signature mark, which could trigger a debate in Parliament.Mr Rees-Mogg, speaking in the House of Commons at an event organised by the Open Europe thinktank today, said peers have to decide whether they love ermine or the EU more.He added: It's striking that 100,000 people can sign a petition so quickly.  JOEY MILLAR Brexit news: Jacob Rees-Mogg has issued the House of Lords with a fiery threatThe Conservative MP is known for his upper-class mannerisms and traditionalist views                    AFPGetty Images1 of 10I think their lordships are playing with fire and it would be a shame to burn down a historic house.The online petition was created by Robert McBride on February 17, meaning it has hit 100,000 signatures in barely two months.The petition reads: &ldquoThe House of Lords is a place of patronage where unelected and unaccountable iniduals hold a disproportionate amount of influence and power which can be used to frustrate the elected representatives of the people.And Mr Rees-Mogg's outburst comes after the Lords delivered two Brexit defeats in short succession to Prime Minister Theresa May, on the customs union and EU law.Their actions prompted Tory MP Daniel Kawczynski to accuse peers of insulting the British people's intelligence by failing to realise a Brexit vote meant leaving the customs union.He said: The time may be coming when where we need to have a national debate on an elected senate.We would only need 100 senators, we don't need the 850 peers we have at the moment.I believe we do need to retain a bicameral system, with checks on the House of Commons.JOEY MILLARBrexit news: Jacob Rees-Mogg hit out at unelected Lords during a Parliament event todayBut I believe the time has come for us to have an elected senate.I believe that any decisions that have to be taken have to be done by people held to account by their electorate.&ldquoPeople in the House of Lords don't have that.

title: Royal baby name Arthur Albert latest odds Kate Middleton birth pictures
story: Richard Fitzwiliams told Express that it would be 48 hours after Kate gave birth to her bundle of joy in the Lindo Wing - before royal fans know the name of the newest member of the Royal Family.And this is because the names his brother and sister, Prince George and Princess Charlotte, were announced two days after they were welcomed into the world.Mr Fitzwilliams tipped Arthur to be the &ldquolikely chosen moniker due to its links with legendary King Arthur, leader of the knights of the Round Table, who supposedly lived in the 5th or 6th century.Albert is also in the running, according to Mr Fitzwilliams, because it would be a fitting tribute to the Queen&rsquos father King George VI, whose name was Albert George.&nbspPA Royal baby watchers will have to wait to find out the prince's name until tomorrow                 BREAKING: Canterbury court EVACUATED as white power sent to judge                Spitting image! Royal baby looks JUST like brother and sister Georg...He told Express: &ldquoI think Arthur with its link to the legendary king and his Round Table, is the likely name, the legend of his court at Camelot has been appropriated by the Kennedys but it&rsquos British.&ldquoAlbert is a tribute to the Queen&rsquos father George VI, (Albert George) known as Bertie and also to Queen Victoria&rsquos beloved husband.&ldquoWe see Victoria through different eyes and this was one of the great royal romances.His predictions come as new odds revealed punters are putting their money on the monikers Arthur and James - Kate&rsquos brothers name - for the royal baby.&nbspKate Middleton and Prince William today welcomed a royal baby boy weighing 8lbs 7oz.1 of 49But Mr Fitzwilliam&rsquos does not think James will make the cut, telling Express William could choose Philip for his son&rsquos middle name in tribute to his grandfather, the Duke of Edinburgh.24 hours since Kate gave birth to her third child and bookmaker Coral has Arthur still firmly at top of its betting for the name at odds of 2-1.James is second favourite at 4-1, with Albert (5-1) and Philip (6-1) the other two names with single figure odds.Coral&rsquos Harry Aitkenhead said: &ldquoThe birth of a royal baby is one of the biggest novelty betting events of any year and with an upcoming wedding interest in the Royal Family has never been greater. We&rsquore being inundated with punters getting their &pound5 or &pound10 on what the name will be and no doubt some will be cheering when it&rsquos announced,. The royal baby will be named today, according to a royal expert &ldquoArthur is the hot favourite at the moment and ever since the birth yesterday our customers have been queuing up to get their bets on. James, Albert and Philip have also been backed and anything else would be a major shock.Meanwhile, James is billed as the most popular name with Ladbrokes.The name of Kate's brother - James - has seen the largest amount of bets and money placed on the moniker.Despite being the favourite in the betting at 21, Arthur is left to settle for second spot in the Top 10 list, followed by Albert (51), Philip (61) and Henry (121).Jessica Bridge of Ladbrokes said: Arthur might be the favourite with the bookies, but it's actually James that's the favourite with punters. It's interesting to see that Royal fans think the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge could name their third child in honour of Prince Philip.She added: Over 100,000 bets have placed across the UK betting industry on the baby name, and punters are eagerly awaiting the announcement from Kensington Palace to see if they will be quids in.&nbsp Kate Middleton and Prince William are expected to announce the name of their royal baby today Corals latest betting odds2-1 Arthur,4-1 James5-1 Albert6-1 Philip12-1 Alexander12-1 Henry14-1 Frederick16-1 Edward16-1 Thomas20-1 Alfred 20-1 Jack20-1 Louis20-1 Michael25-1 Charles25-1 William33-1 BarLadbrokes latest bettingArthur 21James 41Albert 51Philip 61Alexander 121Henry 121Edward 161Frederick 141Thomas 161Alfred 201Jack 201Louis 201Michael 201Charles 251William 251331 Bar

title: Meghan Markle Prince Harry Anzac Day Gallipoli WWI Australia New Zealand
story: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry attended the Anzac Day dawn serviceMeghan ateended the dawn service alongside Prince Harry in central London as they remembered the soldiers from the two countries who paid the ultimate sacrifice in World War 1 (WW1) and subsequent conflicts.Anzac Day marks the anniversary of the start of the&nbsp WW1 Gallipoli landings, and is a national day of remembrance for Australia and New Zealand.Journalist Phillip, F. E. Schuler noted in 1916: &ldquoANZAC! In April&mdasha name unformed, undetermined June&mdashand the worth of a Nation and Dominion proved by the five letters&mdashbound together, by the young army&rsquos leader, Lieut.-General Sir W. Birdwood, in the inspired &ldquoAnzac&mdashAustralian, New Zealand Army Corps.Later today Harry and Meghan will join a Westminster Abbey congregation for a service of commemoration and thanksgiving.                Most Britons would be happy with same-sex royal marriage                Meghan has made REMARKABLE adjustment to royal life, says TV executiveThousands of Anzac troops - Australian and New Zealand Army Corps - died in the ill-fated 1915 campaign on the Turkish peninsula.The Dawn Service was held near Wellington Arch in central London and at the New Zealand memorial where Harry laid a wreath.The Prince, Meghan, Sir Jerry Mateparae and Alexander Downer, the High Commissioners of New Zealand and Australian respectively, then visited the nearby Australian memorial, where Harry laid another wreath and sign the book of remembrance.At 11am at a wreath laying and parade service at the Cenotaph in Whitehall, Prince Harry will also leave a floral tribute on behalf of the Queen.Anzac Day marks the anniversary of the start of the First World War Gallipoli landingsHundreds are expected to take part in the parade including members of veterans associations and ex-service personnel and their families.At Westminster Abbey, Harry and Meghan will join the congregation for a traditional service where the Last Post will be played, an address made and Turkey's Ambassador to the UK will read the famous words of Kemal Ataturk - Turkey's founding father - from Anzac Cove.Prince Harry and Meghan Markle are set to wed on May 19.The Dawn Service will be staged on Wednesday at Wellington ArchThe royal wedding will broadcast on ITV between 9.25am and 3pm.The programme will also includes first-hand accounts of the lengths taken to keep arrangements secret.ITV will also air Royal Wives of Windsor on April 30 and May 1.Additional reporting by Nicole Stinson.

title: Brexit news UK latest EU European Union Lords customs union vote Ireland Theresa May
story: The former foreign secretary said he refuses to take part in the &ldquononsense of the Lords but will be forced to intervene if Remainer peers interfere in the Brexit process.Speaking exclusively to Express., Lord Owen said: &ldquoVarious amendments will go through the House of Commons and then they hopefully will be rejected.&ldquoWhen it comes back I will argue. That&rsquos the moment people like myself will come in and say you have absolutely no constitutional right to interfere in this at all.&ldquoAnd if you have been in the House of Commons and you know the constitutional rights then its time in the House of Lords to speak. But the majority of those people there now have got no experience of what parliament is about.ExpressBrexit news: Lord Owen said that Remainer Peers should back offLord Owen said Peers are best at revising legislation, using the example of lawyers who can improve the interpretation wording within the legislation.He added: &ldquoOnce it has the pretension to be the government of the country then my hackles rise and I think most people realise it is absurd that it could be that way.&ldquoSo, if they are wise they are going to back off it so I think you will find it will be more sound and fury than action.Peers defeated the Government on Wednesday after voting for an amendment to the EU Withdrawal Bill in hope of keeping Britain in the EU&rsquos customs union.A cross-party alliance of Lords, including Tory rebels, put forward to an amendment to the Government&rsquos EU Withdrawal Bill and voted by 348 to 225 in favour of changing the landmark legislation.A statement issued by the Department for Exiting the European Union said the ministry was &ldquodisappointed by the vote.A similar vote is also expected in the House of Commons on Thursday.Prime Minister Theresa May has previously insisted that the UK will leave the common tariff area so it can pursue free trade deals outside the EU.The Conservative MP is known for his upper-class mannerisms and traditionalist views                    AFPGetty Images1 of 10But, according to the Sunday Times, Mrs May&rsquos team have privately admitted the prime minister and her top team will not be crying into our beer if they are forced into a U-turn.Senior Cabinet members David Davis, Liam Fox and Boris Johnson are likely to lead the charge attempting to ensure a swift exit from the EU&rsquos single trading area.Dr Fox, the International Trade Secretary, said the UK would find itself in a &ldquoworse position than it is now if it left the existing arrangements but negotiated a new customs union.He argued having to accept EU rules and lists on doing other deals would make the UK &ldquoless attractive.

title: interest rates banks building societies double standards customers mortgages savers
story: REUTERS  Banks have been criticised over interest rate 'double standards' after the Bank of England rate riseWith speculation rife that the Bank of England could announce a further base rate rise soon, the consumer group Which? looked at how savers and mortgage holders were affected by the previous rise in November, when the base rate was increased from 0.25 per cent to 0.5 per cent.An investigation into how mortgage and savings providers reacted to the rate increase in weeks following it, looked at 327 variable instant access savings accounts and Isas and found that in the five weeks after the base rate rise nearly half (48 per cent) did not register any rate change at all.While just over one in five (21 per cent) had passed on the full 0.25 per cent rise to customers during the period, nearly a third (30 per cent) of accounts saw a rate increase of less than 0.25 per cent.Overall, of 95 providers in the instant access savings market, Which? found that five weeks on from the Bank of England&rsquos announcement, just one in 10 had applied the full 0.25 percentage point rise to all their instant access savings accounts and Isas.                Pound to euro exchange rate: Sterling &lsquounlikely to bounce back&rsquo - STOCKBanks increased rates of borrowers but not saversBut an examination of mortgages showed that for standard variable rate (SVR) mortgages, more than half (53 per cent) of lenders looked at had increased their rate for existing borrowers by the end of 2017 after the base rate was increased.Looking at 76 fixed-rate mortgage providers, the market averages for two-year, three-year and five-year deals all increased between October and December.Gareth Shaw, Which? money expert, said: &ldquoThe last base rate rise saw clear double standards from some financial institutions.Ahead of a possible future rate rise, we&rsquore calling on banks and providers to be fair to their customers across the board.Fancy living in the farmhouse from The Walking Dead or the mansion from The Woman In Black? Find out if you could afford them with new research from Which? Mortgage Advisers.                      Momentum Pictures&bullWhich1 of 11Could you afford these famous haunted houses?A spokeswoman for trade association UK Finance said: &ldquoAny change in interest rates will see banks looking to balance the increased cost of customer borrowing with the savings returns to ensure that their products are competitive.&ldquoMortgage and savings rates are determined by a number of different factors and external costs that do not correlate to the base rate when interest rates are as low as they have been for several years.&ldquoMost mortgage borrowers pay a fixed rate and so would see no change while their current deal lasts.&ldquoFor both mortgages and savings, banks also now make it easier for customers to compare and switch products, and these improvements will help customers shop around for the best deal, should interest rates rise.

title: Alfie Evans update parents giving mouth to mouth resuscitation Tom Evans Alder Hey
story: Getty &bull PATom Evans made the claim outside Alder Hey hospital in LiverpoolTom Evans, the father of Alfie, made the claim outside Alder Hey hospital in Liverpool and stated that the Court of Appeal was willing to hear his case again.He declared: Both Kate and I had to give him mouth to mouth resuscitation to keep him alive because his lips turned blue.We were doing what a nurse should have been doing to sustain his life.Now they are saying that he looks really good but we all know he should be in Italy right now.                Alfie Evans UPDATE: High Court rules ill baby cannot got to Italy                Alfie Evans news: Piers Morgan speaks out against judge&rsquos ruling The court has reached out to us and said it can set aside three judges tonight to hear his case again.Mr Evans added that the decision meant &ldquoAlfie could be in Italy tomorrow night.He went on: It means there is a chance that Alfie could be in Italy tomorrow night if we are allowed back in court.The father of Alfie stated he is &ldquonot going to give up on him and added that &ldquo22 hours after having his life support pulled, he is &ldquostill fighting.Alfie has a degenerative neurological condition which has not been definitively diagnosed after being born in a semi-vegetative state.                    Facebook1 of 12Alfie Evans pictured in hospital with his motherMr Evans went on: In the earlier court hearing the doctors were saying they were scared of the protesters but we have police officers with tasers around Alfie's room.Now they are saying we might be able to take Alfie home but I am going to keep on fighting for him.The doctors said he would die within five minutes of him being taken off a life support machine but he is here 22 hours later still fighting.He is making vocal noises and he is breathing. I am not going to give up on him.In a recent statement, Alder Hey hospital iterated the High Court&rsquos decision and said its &ldquotop priority therefore remains in ensuring Alfie receives the care he deserves to ensure his comfort, dignity and privacy are maintained throughout.The statement read: This evening the High Court again ruled that it is in Alfie&rsquos best interests to continue with the end of life care plan developed by the clinical team who have cared for him throughout.GettyMr Evans added that the decision meant 'Alfie could be in Italy tomorrow night'AFP &bull GettyAlfie Evans&rsquos parents have claimed they are giving the baby 'mouth to mouth resuscitation'Our top priority therefore remains in ensuring Alfie receives the care he deserves to ensure his comfort, dignity and privacy are maintained throughout.&ldquoThis includes working closely with Kate and Tom as they spend this precious time together with him.We would be grateful if respect and consideration is shown to all our staff, patients and families at the hospital at this difficult time.

title: Brexit news Theresa May blasted for operating in parallel universe over Brexit Greg Clark
story: GettyTheresa May has been blasted for 'operating in a parallel universe' over BrexitThe Commons Public Accounts Committee voiced &ldquograve concerns over the BEIS&rsquo reliance on the proposed 21-month transition period that would keep the UK waiting until 2021 for its independence.The Chairwoman of the committee, Meg Hillier, declared: The Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy appears to be operating in a parallel universe where urgency is an abstract concept with no bearing on the Brexit process.We have grave concerns about this apparent complacency, compounded by the lack of transparency on the department's progress with what in some cases will be critical projects.BEIS, led by Business Secretary Greg Clark, was also attacked for making &ldquovirtually no attempt to change up its priorities to ensure Brexit was delivered.                Nigel Farage BLASTS 'clever' Macron for uniting Trump AGAINST UK                Farage blasts Sadiq Khan and John Bercow for leaving UK behind The committee issued Mr Clark with a two-month deadline to declare what programmes can be altered at the department in exchange for Brexit priorities.The BEIS believed an additional 350 staff were needed to deal with leaving the EU - it has currently recruited 305 extra employees.The Treasury gave the department an extra &pound35million for preparations between 2017 and 2018.The committee&rsquos report lambasting BEIS also stated concern at the department&rsquos ability to push its 150 pieces of legislation through Parliament before the UK officially leaves the trade bloc.Another report, from trade association Acita and the Institute of Economic Affairs think-tank, stated that &ldquopractical steps were needed to prepare for the UK&rsquos withdrawal from the European Union&rsquos Customs Union.It added that further investment for infrastructure at borders was needed.A spokesman for BEIS defended its actions and insisted that it is &ldquofocused on getting the best deal for the UK.GettyTheresa May was dealt another Brexit blow by the House of Lords last weekThey went on: Along with the whole of government, BEIS is focused on getting the best deal for the UK and ensuring a smooth transition for businesses, consumers and workers.Since this report was written, BEIS has received &pound185million of extra funding to help deliver a successful Brexit by employing an increased number of staff on our Europe work, identifying the most pressing legislative challenges and remaining ahead of schedule by recruiting high-calibre staff to ensure we prepare thoroughly and effectively.Theresa May was dealt another Brexit blow last week when the Government suffered a defeat on its EU Withdrawal Bill thanks to the House of Lords.GettyThe BEIS is led by led by Business Secretary Greg ClarkPeers voted for amendments that aim to keep the door open to remaining in the bitter bloc&rsquos customs union.In response, leading Leave campaigner Jacob Rees-Mogg has since skewered the House of Lords and issued a scathing warning.The Conservative declared the body was &ldquoplaying with fire by blocking Brexit and &ldquoit would be a shame to burn the House down.

title: UK news press freedom censorship newspapers Theresa May Max Mosely
story: Online intimidation against prominent journalists and the threat of state regulation has left the UK in 40th place in the 2018 World Press Freedom Index which was compiled by Reporters without Borders.The UK has fallen 18 places since the index was first published in 2002 and is below South Africa (28), Lithuania (36) and Trinidad and Tobago (39).Rebecca Vincent, UK Bureau Director of non-profit group RSF - which promotes press freedom - said the UK&rsquos place in the 180-country ranking was &ldquoembarassing.She added: &ldquoThis is unacceptable for a country that plays an important international standard-setting role when it comes to human rights and fundamental freedoms.The UK has fallen 18 places since the index was first published in 2002                Professor&rsquos work arguing for colonialism CENSORED after death threats                Left wing activist EMBARRASSED over question in fiery BBC clash&ldquoWe must examine the longer-term trend of worrying moves to restrict press freedom and hold the UK Government to account.RSF has criticised threats to press freedom in the past year.This includes proposed reforms to the Official Secrets Act that could have led to journalists being imprisoned for 15 years for obtaining leaked documents.Britain is also the only country where court action has been initiated over stories about tax avoidance after law firm Appleby started legal proceedings against  and the BBC.RSF has criticised threats to press freedom in the past yearLaura Kuenssberg had to be assigned security personnel when attending a Labour conference after receiving death threats.The News Media Association which represents newspapers urged politicians to &ldquoprotect media freedom and safeguard a vibrant press in the UK.A spokeswoman said: We have seen repeated attempts by the House of Lords to hijack legislation such as the current Data Protection Bill, to enforce state-backed press regulation which would have a chilling effect on investigative journalism.&ldquoThis is a grave threat to press freedom and could lead to the closure of newspapers.Theresa May vowed press freedom will never change while she is Prime Minister Theresa May vowed press freedom &ldquowill never change while she is Prime Minister after privacy campaigner Max Mosley was engulfed in a race-hate row.Mrs May made the pledge to the Commons after concern was raised about the multi-millionaire&rsquos links to senior politicians and new media regulator Impress.Former Formula One boss Mr Mosley, 77, was on the back foot over a by-election campaign leaflet from six decades ago which linked non-white immigrants with sexually transmitted diseases, tuberculosis and leprosy.Speaking at Prime Minister&rsquos Questions, Mrs May said: &ldquoSome people will have been surprised to learn of those links with some leading politicians. But can I also say to her that I absolutely agree with her that a free press is very important.It underpins our democracy and whatever they say about us, whatever they write about us, actually it&rsquos important that they are able to hold politicians, the powerful, to account and they are able to shine a light in some of the darkest corners of our society.&ldquoAs far as I&rsquom concerned while I&rsquom Prime Minister that will never change.

title: alfie evans update latest news Facebook liverpool alder hey
story: A spokeswoman for lawyers the Christian Legal Centre, representing Alfie&rsquos parents, said the case is due to be heard in the Court of Appeal on Wednesday afternoon.In the latest development in the High Court in Manchester on Tuesday, Mr Justice Hayden described the tot as &ldquocourageous and a &ldquowarrior, but said the case had now reached its &ldquofinal chapter.But the judge ruled out the family&rsquos wishes to take Alfie to the Bambino Gesu hospital in Rome for specialist treatment, following interventions from the Pope and the Italian authorities.Mr Justice Hayden rejected claims from Alfie&rsquos dad Tom Evans that his son was &ldquosignificantly better that first thought because he had been breathing unaided for 20 hours after doctors first withdrew his life support on Monday night.Instead, the judge said the best the child&rsquos parents could hope for was to &ldquoexplore the options of removing him from intensive care either to a ward, a hospice or his home.But a doctor treating Alfie, who cannot be named for legal reasons, said that for Alfie to be allowed home it would require a &ldquosea change in attitude from the child&rsquos family, and they feared that in the &ldquoworst case they would try to take the boy abroad.                Alfie Evans latest: Queen asked to intervene, petition reaches 100,000                Alfie Evans FRESH HOPE: Court of Appeal AGREES to hear parents' caseSpeaking to reporters outside Alder Hey Children&rsquos Hospital in Liverpool on Tuesday night, where Alfie is being treated, Mr Evans said his 23-month-old son had confounded doctors&rsquo expectations when he continued to live after life support was withdrawn.&ldquoThe court of appeal have reached out to us and said they are going to set back three judges to hear the case.&ldquoIn reality, he could be in Italy right now. We all know the military air force are ready to take him and a team of doctors are there.&ldquoWe've also got a German air ambulance team, who attempted to take him in the first place, ready... the reality is these people are eager to get him out of the country and I'm not giving up because Alfie's breathing away, he's not suffering.Mr Evans revealed that Alfie had at times needed to be helped with his breathing, adding: &ldquoAt some point I had to give him mouth-to-mouth because his lips went blue and he was really fighting with his breathing so me and his mum were giving him mouth-to-mouth.During a separate three-hour hearing on Tuesday at the Family Division of the High Court in Manchester, Paul Diamond from the Christian Legal Centre suggested the alleged change in this position meant the court should consider its decision on allowing Alfie to travel abroad.The judge rejected claims from Tom Evans that his son was &ldquosignificantly better than first thought Mr Diamond handed the court a witness statement from Mr Evans in which he suggested his son&rsquos health was &ldquosignificantly better than first thought since life support was withdrawn at 9:17pm on Monday, as he was continuing to live and breathe.But Mr Justice Hayden said in his ruling: &ldquoThe sad truth is that it is not.&ldquoWith little, indeed no hesitation, I reject that.Instead, the judge said Alfie&rsquos continued life was a &ldquoshaft of right and a &ldquospecial opportunity for his parents to spend time with him, not the time for more legal manoeuvres.The judge also criticised the &ldquomalign hand of one of the family&rsquos advisers, law student Pavel Stroilov, who had, the court heard, been party to Mr Evans lodging a private prosecution of Alder Hey Hospital doctors, allegedly for murder.Mr Justice Hayden said that in fact the hospital had provided &ldquoworld class care for Alfie.Tom Evans told reporters that Alfie had confounded doctors' expectationsFollowing the hearing, a spokesman for Alder Hey said it was working closely with the youngster&rsquos parents, but that its &ldquotop priority therefore remains in ensuring Alfie receives the care he deserves to ensure his comfort, dignity and privacy are maintained throughout.In a statement Professor Russell Viner, President of the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, said decisions to withold or withdraw treatment from a child are not made lightly.Mr Viner said there is a clear and compassionate framework to guide practice which includes three sets of circumstances when withdrawing life-sustaining treatment may be considered.&nbspThese are if treatment is unable or unlikely to result in the child living much longer where treatment may prolong life but will cause the child unacceptable pain and suffering and if an older child with a life limiting illness repeatedly makes it clear they do not want treatment and this decision is supported by their parents and doctors.&nbspAs healthcare professionals involved in the care of babies, children and young people, the priority has to be the child.Every action and decisions is taken in the best interests of the child, and decisions on care, including the withdrawal of treatment, are always made with the involvement of parents.Alfie Evans supporters have been demonstrating outside Alder Hey Children's HospitalWe cannot comment on the specifics of the case - only the medical team treating Alfie, and the legal team, will know the exact details and they are bound by patient confidentiality.However, we feel it is important for the public to know that decisions to withhold or withdraw treatment from a child are not made lightly.Decisions on whether to withdraw treatment from a child are unfortunately ones that need to be made frequently. The model is always for doctors to work closely with parents to agree on the best course of action for the child.In the vast majority of cases an equal decision is made to withdraw treatment and it is rare that there is disagreement. The cases where this is a significant difference in view are the ones that grab the media headlines.

title: brexit news david davis questions commons select committee exiting european union
story: David Davis is giving evidence to the Commons committee on exiting EuropeThe Committee Chairman, former Labour front-bencher Hilary Benn, asked Mr Davis how long MPs would have to consider the withdrawal agreement before the &ldquomeaningful vote?Mr Davis said he did not know but wanted to let Parliament vote on it before the European parliament votes on it.He said all the elements of the negotiation will have been revealed to MPs &ldquoway before the vote - all except the very last bit.He said there will be a statement to MPs and the vote would take place &ldquonot too long after that.Mr Davis pledged MPs will know most of the details of withdrawal agreement long before deal is agreed and said they would receive an &ldquoeconomic assessment.Mr Davis confirmed MPs will be able to table amendments to the &ldquomeaningful vote motion approving Brexit withdrawal agreement and joked with Mr Benn that he did not know how to put forward and unamendable motion but was happy to take lessons.He insisted the Government planned to take any amendments seriously, saying it would not have a vote if it were not going to take it seriously.The Brexit Secretary said the Government wanted to conclude negotiating a trade treaty with EU before March 2019 and did not accept suggestions that talks would continue into the transition period,He said there were six months between the withdrawal agreement being agreed and Brexit and it was not the Government&rsquos intention to allow the trade negotiations to spill over into the transition.He says he wanted the political agreement on trade in the autumn to be very detailed and wanted it turned into a treaty within six months and concluded before March 2019.MORE FOLLOWS...
